evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently present during the early phase of the hist_pair_engine_t1 event on Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is strong resistance to defeaters against the communication/coordination breakdown explanation, as alternative causes do not adequately account for the observed coordination failures among the crew.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features observed in the hist_pair_engine_t1_early event, including misaligned crew actions and delayed information exchange.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently present during the early phase of the hist_pair_engine_t1 event on Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: Communication via interphone and actions described reflect crew coordination status.
The event phase corresponds to the early phase of hist_pair_engine_t1.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, consistent communication and coordination without errors or if procedural deviations better explained the event.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 shows communication among crew and coordination actions during pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown during the early phase of the event. The discriminator favors communication breakdown over procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting whether actions reflect breakdown or procedural deviation

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key features observed in the hist_pair_engine_t1_early event, including misaligned crew actions and delayed information exchange.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely, and aligned crew communication and coordination without misaligned actions or delays, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 directly describe crew communication and coordination actions including misaligned actions (e.g., trainee stopping pushback and instructor taking over) and delayed stopping beyond the TRP, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists in the extent to which communication delays versus procedural deviations contributed, but evidence favors communication breakdown.

node.statement: There is strong resistance to defeaters against the communication/coordination breakdown explanation, as alternative causes do not adequately account for the observed coordination failures among the crew.

assumptions: The observed communication and coordination attempts were representative of the overall crew interaction.
No significant mechanical or environmental failures contributed to the event beyond what is described.
defeaters: If evidence showed that procedural deviations alone (without communication failures) caused the coordination failures, or if mechanical or environmental factors fully explained the event, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H1-H5) shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, yet the aircraft still passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier, indicating coordination failure rather than procedural deviation. This supports strong resistance to alternative causes and favors the communication/coordination breakdown explanation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from coordination failure without more explicit behavioral markers
